case_name: Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1954 filed by Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga against Patna High Court judgment dated February 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1954. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 19, 1952, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judl. Case No. 244 of 1949. Sen, S. K. Majumdar and I. N. Shrojj, for the appellant. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India, B. K. Saran and R. C. Prasad, for the respondent. 1959. May 15.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J. on May 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. May 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal, with the special leave of this Court, has been filed by Maharajadhiraja Sir Kameshwar Singh of Darbhanga  hereinafter referred to as the assessee  against the judgment of the High Court of Patna dated February 19, 1952,

facts.text: Patna High Court answered two questions in affirmative in Misc. Judl. Case No. 244 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: by which the High Court answered in the affirmative the following two questions referred to it under s. 25 1  of the Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1938 Whether in view of the circumstances of the case, and particularly the manner in which, after due companysideration, the learned Agricultural Incometax Officer in his first judgment dated the 5th January, 1946, had held that the assessee was number liable to be assessed for the receipt on account of the zarpeshgi lease,

facts.text: Assessment year 1944-45 corresponding to 1351 Fasli.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case lie within a very narrow company. pass. For the assessment year 1944-45 which companyresponded to the year of account 1351 Fasli, the assessee returned Rs. 37,43,520 as his agricultural income.

facts.text: Assessee returned Rs. 37,43,520 as agricultural income for 1944-45.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1944-45 which companyresponded to the year of account 1351 Fasli, the assessee returned Rs. 37,43,520 as his agricultural income.

facts.text: Assessee claimed deduction of Rs. 9,42,137-3-10 1/2 including Rs. 2,82,192 paid to Tekari Raj on account of zarpeshgi lease.

anchor.surface_text: He claimed a deduction of Rs. 9,42,137-3-10 1/2 on account of land revenue, rent etc., including a sum of Rs. 2,82,192 shown to have been paid to the Tekari Raj from which two leasehold properties were taken on zarpeshgi lease by indentures dated August 15, 1931, and January 31, 1936, respectively. The amount was sought to be deducted as a capital receipt.

facts.text: Two zarpeshgi leases from Tekari Raj dated August 15, 1931 and January 31, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: including a sum of Rs. 2,82,192 shown to have been paid to the Tekari Raj from which two leasehold properties were taken on zarpeshgi lease by indentures dated August 15, 1931, and January 31, 1936, respectively. The amount was sought to be deducted as a capital receipt. The Agricultural Income-tax Officer of Darbhanga by his order dated December 28, 1945 accepted this companytention,

facts.text: Agricultural Income-tax Officer (Darbhanga) order dated December 28, 1945 accepted Rs. 2,82,192 as capital receipt and exempted from tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Agricultural Income-tax Officer of Darbhanga by his order dated December 28, 1945 accepted this companytention, and exempted the amount from payment of agricultural income-tax. He observed Out of Rs. 9,42,137-3-10 1/2 claimed on account of Land Revenue and rent, Rs. 2,82,192 is shown as payment to Tekari Raj and then taken towards the realisation of Zarpeshgi Loan to self. I have gone through the bond of Gaya Zarpeshgi Lease.

facts.text: Assessment approved by Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax on January 4, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was approved by the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax on January 4, 1946, and on the day following, the Income-tax Officer passed his formal order and issued a demand numberice.

facts.text: Formal order and demand notice issued on January 5, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and on the day following, the Income-tax Officer passed his formal order and issued a demand numberice. The assessee paid two instalments out of three, when on March 22, 1946, the Agricultural Income-tax Officer recorded the following order -

facts.text: Assessee paid two instalments out of three.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee paid two instalments out of three, when on March 22, 1946, the Agricultural Income-tax Officer recorded the following order - It appears that some agricultural income from Gaya Zarpeshgi lease which should have been taxed for the year 1944-45  1351 Fasli  has escaped assessment.

facts.text: On March 22, 1946, AITO recorded escaped assessment from Gaya Zarpeshgi lease and issued notice u/s 26 fixing May 20, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: when on March 22, 1946, the Agricultural Income-tax Officer recorded the following order - It appears that some agricultural income from Gaya Zarpeshgi lease which should have been taxed for the year 1944-45  1351 Fasli  has escaped assessment. Issue numberice under section 26 fixing the 20th May 1947.

facts.text: Supplementary assessment order assessed Rs. 39,512-6-0 tax on Rs. 2,52,879.

anchor.surface_text: After the assessee appeared, a supplementary assessment order was passed and Rs. 39,512-6-0 were assessed as tax on Rs. 2,52,879.

facts.text: AITO reasons: assessee to remain in possession, enjoy usufruct, fixed thika rent Rs. 1,000 annually.

anchor.surface_text: In deciding the matter, the Agricultural Income-tax Officer gave the following reasons According to the terms of the lease the assessee is to remain in possession and enjoy the usufruct of the lands given in lease for a fixed number of years on payment of an annual thica rent of Rs. 1,000 to the lessor and thus satisfy himself for the entire amount of companysideration money of the zarpeshgi lease in question.

facts.text: AITO acted under s. 26 of Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The Agricultural Income-tax Officer purported to act under s. 26 of the Bihar Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1938  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The assessee appealed.

facts.text: Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax reversed AITO's supplementary assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed. The Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax reversed the decision. He pointed out that the agricultural income from Tekari Raj property was returned by the assessee but was held to be exempt and thus companyld number be said to have escaped assessment so as to bring the case within s. 26 of the Act.

facts.text: Board of Revenue, Bihar referred two questions to Patna High Court on February 7, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Province of Bihar  as it was then called  ,moved the Board of Revenue, Bihar which by a resolution dated February 7, 1948, referred the two questions to the High Court of Patna. The Board did number express any opinion on the two questions.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave after High Court refused.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, both the questions were answered in favour of the State of Bihar. Leave having been refused by the High Court, the assessee applied for, and obtained special leave from this Court.

facts.text: Zarpeshgi lease consideration Rs. 17,00,000 approx, possession for 28 years.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee is that it may be agricultural income in the hands of the Tekari Raj but -in his hands it was capital receipt and in repayment of the loan of about Rs. 17,00,000 paid to Ram Bhuwaneshwari Kuer.

facts.text: Documents are indentures of lease, payment Rs. 17,16,000 for possession 28 years, no express loan term, no interest, no redemption right.

anchor.surface_text: From these documents it is clear that in companysideration of a payment of Rs. 17,16,000 the lessee was placed in possession of the leasehold property for 28 years. There is numberexpress term which makes the sum a loan returnable either by repayment or by the enjoyment of the usufruct. There is numberinterest fixed or right of redemption granted.

facts.text: Supreme Court held AITO had jurisdiction under s. 26 to revise order.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons we have given, we are of opinion that the Agricultural Income-tax Officer was companypetent under s. 26 of the Act to assess an item of income which he had omitted to tax earlier, even though in the return that income was included and the Agricultural Income-tax Officer then thought that it was exempt.

facts.text: Supreme Court held income from leasehold properties taxable as agricultural income, not capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that it was so, and that the Agricultural Income-tax Officer was right when he assessed it to agricultural income-tax. The income was number the income of money-lending, and this does number depend upon the character of the recipient.

issues.text: Whether in view of the circumstances of the case, and particularly the manner in which, after due consideration, the learned Agricultural Income-tax Officer in his first judgment dated the 5th January, 1946, had held that the assessee was not liable to be assessed for the receipt on account of the zarpeshgi lease, the learned Agricultural Income-tax Officer has jurisdiction to revise his own order under s. 26 of the Act

issues.text: Whether if he had the jurisdiction to revise his own order, under section 26 of the Act, the income from the zarpeshgi lease of the assessee was taxable under the Act.

arguments.claim: Generality of 'any reason' has no bearing on construction of 'escaped assessment'; assessment is entire process, returned and exempt income did not escape

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the assessee contends that the generality of the words any reason has no bearing upon the construction of the words escaped assessment , that the word assessment does not connote the final determination to tax income but the entire process by which the result is reached, and that inasmuch as the income was actually returned and held to be exempt, there was no question of an escaped assessment because it passed through the processing of income.

holdings.text: The Agricultural Income-tax Officer was competent under s. 26 of the Act to assess an item of income which he had omitted to tax earlier, even though in the return that income was included and the Agricultural Income-tax Officer then thought that it was exempt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Income returned but deliberately not taxed after consideration escapes assessment; follows Kamal Singh and High Court preponderance; distinguishes contrary precedents; 'for any reason' has wide import without need for fresh information.

holdings.text: The words of s. 26 of the Act do not involve possessing of or coming by some fresh information. The use of the words 'any reason' which are of wide import dispenses with those conditions by which s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act is circumscribed.

anchor.surface_text: We may say at once that the words of s. 26 of the Act do number involve possessing of or companying by some fresh information. The section says If for any reason any agricultural income chargeable to agricultural income-tax has escaped assessment for any financial year the Agricultural Income-tax Officer may proceed to assess such income The use of the words any reason which are of wide import dispenses with those companyditions by which s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act is circumscribed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'for any reason' broader than s.34 IT Act; no requirement for external information or change of mind restriction.

holdings.text: The transaction was one of zarpeshgi lease and not a lease with a mortgage; in consideration of payment of Rs. 17,16,000 lessee placed in possession for 28 years with no express loan term, no interest, no right of redemption, no personal liability.

anchor.surface_text: From these documents it is clear that in companysideration of a payment of Rs. 17,16,000 the lessee was placed in possession of the leasehold property for 28 years. There is numberexpress term which makes the sum a loan returnable either by repayment or by the enjoyment of the usufruct. There is numberinterest fixed or right of redemption granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies tests from Mulla's Transfer of Property Act to lease documents; no loan characteristics despite petitioner arguments on clauses.

holdings.text: The income from the zarpeshgi lease was taxable agricultural income under the Act; Agricultural Income-tax Officer was right to assess it; not money-lending income depending on recipient's character; Thika profits derived from land.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that it was so, and that the Agricultural Income-tax Officer was right when he assessed it to agricultural income-tax. The income was number the income of money-lending, and this does number depend upon the character of the recipient.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Leasehold income from land is agricultural; lessee enjoys usufruct; rejects capital receipt/loan repayment claim; taxable regardless of lessor.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney- General also relied strongly upon a recent decision of this Court in Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 4 , where Gajendragadkar, J., after a review of all the authorities, held that s. 34 of the Indian Income- tax Act was applicable to a case where an item of income was returned but deliberately and after companysideration, was held to be number liable to tax. Learned counsel for the assessee contends that the point was left open in that case, and refers to Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 5 as having held the contrary.

precedents.case_name: Kamal Singh v Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 34 applicable even where income returned but deliberately held not liable to tax after consideration
precedents.cited_holding: Even if assessee submitted return, if ITO erroneously fails to tax part of assessable income, it escapes assessment

precedents.citation: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 5

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the assessee contends that the point was left open in that case, and refers to Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar and Orissa 5 as having held the contrary. Before referring to the other authorities of the High Courts, it will be proper to see if the two cases of the Supreme Court are in point or not, and if so, which of them.

precedents.case_name: Messrs Chatturam Horilram Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar and Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Contrary view to Kamal Singh on escaped assessment

precedents.citation: Kamakshya Narain Singh Commissioner of Income-tax 6

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before the Income-tax Officer that this interest was number assessable to income-tax being agricultural income, in view of the decision of the Patna High Court in Kamakshya Narain Singh Commissioner of Income-tax 6 . The Income-tax Officer did number accept this contention on the ground that an appeal was pending against the Patna High Courts decision, before the Privy Council.

precedents.case_name: Kamakshya Narain Singh v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Interest on arrears of rent is agricultural income not taxable as income-tax

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakshya Narain Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1948, the Privy Council reversed the Patna High Courts decision. The judgment of the Privy Council is reported in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Kamakshya Narain Singh 1 . The Income-tax Officer then issued a notice under s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act, and after hearing the party assessed the sum of Rs. 93,604.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Kamakshya Narain Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Interest on arrears of rent is taxable income

precedents.citation: Rajendra Nath Mukerjee v. Income-tax Commissioner 2

anchor.surface_text: In all the cases where a contrary view was taken, reliance was placed upon the decision of the Privy Council in Rajendra Nath Mukerjee v. Income-tax Commissioner 2 particularly a passage wherein it was observed The fact that s. 34 requires a notice to be served calling for a return of income which had escaped assessment strongly suggests that income which has already been duly returned for assessment cannot be said to have escaped assessment within the statutory meaning.

precedents.case_name: Rajendra Nath Mukerjee v Income-tax Commissioner
precedents.cited_proposition: Income already returned cannot escape assessment
precedents.cited_holding: Income returned but not yet assessed does not escape assessment

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships held that the expression has escaped assessment should not be read as equivalent to has not been assessed because so to do gives too narrow a meaning to the word assessment and too wide a meaning to the word escaped. That those observations were related to the facts then before their Lordships is clear from the following passage In re Lachhiram Basantlal 1 that Income has not escaped assessment if there are pending at the time proceedings for the assessment of the assessee's income which have not yet terminated in a final assessment thereof.

precedents.cited_proposition: Income does not escape if assessment proceedings pending

precedents.citation: Maharaja Bikram Kishore v. Province of Assam 1

anchor.surface_text: Most of the cases are also considered in the judgment of Harries, C. J., and Mukherjea, J. as he then was in Maharaja Bikram Kishore v. Province of Assam 1 . In all the cases where a contrary view was taken, reliance was placed upon the decision of the Privy Council in Rajendra Nath Mukerjee v. Income-tax Commissioner particularly a passage wherein it was observed

precedents.case_name: Maharaja Bikram Kishore v Province of Assam
precedents.cited_proposition: Review of authorities on escaped assessment

precedents.citation: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the assessee argued that the decision of this Court in Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar Orissa 1 discloses a different view, and that we should follow it in preference to the later view of Gajendragadkar, J. We do not think that in the case last cited the point was the same.

precedents.case_name: Messrs Chatturam Horilram Ltd v Commissioner of Income-tax Bihar Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Income escaping due to lacuna not attributable to authorities

anchor.surface_text: We may say at once that the words of s. 26 of the Act do number involve possessing of or companying by some fresh information. The section says If for any reason any agricultural income chargeable to agricultural income-tax has escaped assessment for any financial year the Agricultural Income-tax Officer may proceed to assess such income The use of the words any reason which are of wide import dispenses with those companyditions by which s. 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act is circumscribed.
